key_points: The UK's evacuation from Kabul airport is in its final stages after failing to persuade the US to extend the 31 August deadline.
Two explosions at the airport killed 90 people, but the UK's withdrawal pace remained unchanged.
The UK can't maintain Kabul airport operations without the US due to lack of sufficient troops, air traffic control, intelligence, surveillance, and air protection.
Nick Reynolds highlighted the UK's limited transport aircraft capability for an effective evacuation.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said only the US could manage a mission of this scale and complexity.
About 6,000 US troops and over 1,000 UK troops, among others from NATO countries, have been present at the airport.
The UK has evacuated over 13,000 people but acknowledges that not everyone eligible has been evacuated.
Defence Secretary Ben Wallace mentioned loosening passenger number limits to maximize evacuations, leaving some military equipment behind.
Prime Minister Boris Johnson anticipates a 'second phase' for further evacuations under a reasonable approach with the Taliban.
President Joe Biden insists on leaving by 31 August, depending on the Taliban's 'self-interest' for airport perimeter security.
spokespersons: Nick Reynolds (Royal United Services Institute think tank)
